profile.name: Nick Saraev
profile.bio: Live streaming my daily work, my one-off shower thoughts, and anything & everything else. A no-algorithm alternative to X (after I deleted my social media).

posts.content: Recorded 9 more videos for Instagram, including sponsorships.

Interesting development: Maker School and other communities feel more like "being inside". I don't worry about sharing stuff with them, they're (essentially) inside my own house! YouTube and Instagram feel more like "being outside". I worry about sharing stuff with them, they're (essentially) strangers. Need to turn the outside into the inside.
Completed Maker School management for Jan 19 2026.
Finished 3 month roadmap for new client.
Scraped/processed ~20K leads for next batch of campaign.

Up to 14 days of the routine now.

Some highlights:

- 14 workouts (gains returning fast).
- 14 pieces of content (video muscle officially back).
- 14 days of consistent community mgmt (gonna get my little ðŸ”¥ emoji).
- 9 days of fantastic, >95% sleep.
- In one week, I went from a WHOOP age of 30.1 > 29.6. Essentially, based on health markers, I "saved" around half a year.

Some broader wins and self-discoveries:
- Took an overnight trip to Edmonton to see some family and friends. While sleep has suffered the last two nights, I still crushed the routine.
- Feel my bar for perfectionism lowering again. This is big and one of my low-hanging fruits for this year. Even 90% Nick is, like, 400% the information density of the average content you find on the internet. 
- Shows me I can sustain the routine even in suboptimal situations.
- Have been extremely happy. I believe this is (of course) because of the daily exercise, but also smaller things like daily sunlight exposure, daily walks to/from gym, etc. Making iterative progress in my health is clearly extremely important to me.

Additionally, I have been *more* productive with the rest of my career. I have found that some activities drain energy, but others improve energy. My routine actually counterintuitively increases my capacity for work.

Onto another two weeks!
Completed Maker School management for Jan 18 2026.
Completed Maker School management for Jan 17 2026.
Wowâ€”had ~20mg of caffeine at 4:00pm yesterday and it absolutely TRASHED my sleep. Was hitting ~100% every night up until now. Good reminder.
Recorded another piece of content for Maker School.
Completed Maker School management for Jan 16, 2025.

Writing course material is actually really easy. Workflow:

- Take Gwern's "style manual" (https://gwern.net/system-prompts-2025) and make some minor adjustments for my own TOV.
- Give Claude Code a brief outline, as well as snippets of your work for examples.
- It generates you a rough draft. Go through the rough draft, edit where necessary for impending tone of voice problems, get fine draft.
- Give it a once-over, screenshot sections every 5-6 paragraphs for visual aid, spell/grammar check, and done.

I wrote the whole thing (13 modules) in around 2 hours. Was putting this off for like two weeks. 

Now I just have to turn on the camera. Easy!

Read another 400 pages of Demon in White. What a great book.
Recorded another longform community exclusive for Maker School.

Uploaded final Weekly Office Hour for MMWM.

Re: the routineâ€”there will be long travel days, and situations in which it is infeasible to do stuff like record content in the morning. I will do my best to get it done regardless. But in extenuating circumstances, that's what the breathing room is for (~5 days/month). I will also shift the allocation of my content, so some days it'll be for Maker School, other days it'll be for YouTube, etc. This freedom and flexibility combined with the constraint is ideal, I think. 

I arrived at this by simply asking myself: what would Nick in a year wish he did a year ago? My health and my brand are my two biggest priorities right now.

Set goals with accountability group. TLDR I'm doing my morning habit 300/365 days this year. The specifics around content creation will probably evolve, but exercise and supplementation are non-negotiable. Happiest I've been in a long time!

Took five minutes and I found:

1. https://x.com/trq212/status/2011523109871108570
2. https://x.com/tbpn/status/2011547033719689590
3. https://x.com/GoogleAI/status/2011545972724425183

I'd have interesting things to say about all three. Cliff notes:

1. Massive development. MCP ease-of-use is the primary advantage to it over other frameworks (Skills, DOE). But context rot is the main drawback. This solves context rot, makes tools like 5x as token efficient at the cost of an additional lookup step. You can now load Claude Code, use something like mcpmarket.com/leaderboards to slap on a half dozen MCPs in ~10 mins, and have a fully fledged operating system (that actually works).  
2. Anthropic, Google, OpenAI are all experimenting with designing on-the-fly interfaces. Because a picture is worth a thousand words; bandwidth wise, you can transmit an incredible amount more information visually than textually. And as you see with Claude Code, these things are fantastic at frontend. You can oneshot most big apps with just a screenshot tool, HTML, and some Tailwind CSS. What if, instead of communicating via a little chat window in an IDE, it spun up whole frontends for you? This is the future of automation: AI will spin up beautiful, sexy interfaces every time you prompt it.
3. Biggest issue right now is just context. Google inherently has access to everything a personal intelligence would ever need, solving the context problem. If they don't fuck up their UX, like they've done with a bunch of other launches, this would be quite the killer app.

Production workflow: #1 is obviously the biggest development. So I'd come up with some hook, say it, then take each of these and then run with them. I'd probably get ~5min ad-libbing on each topic. OBS, Auphonic for audio enhancements, instant upload. Over time, come up with semi-automated workflows to make the video more interesting where necessary.

Only issue is thumbnails. Do I just patent some sort of super stand-out-ey background + take a screenshot of a logo or whatever? I could build a few templates in Canva and then cycle them, I suppose. One with me talking about a thing (face) with text on the left, another with just app logos in the middle, another with app logos on the right and some text on the left, another with my face on the right and app logos on the left and perhaps some question marks or whatever. I think this is reasonable. I'll use my real face, too, since people are getting tired of the AI stuff.

Okay, I think this is it! End result would be similar to https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=LLe2ghr6Oug, just punchier and more interesting. All that is left for me is to act. I bet I could bang out >300 of these this year.

How should I create content? 

For the last week, I've done bespoke videos for Maker School. They've been between 15 to 30 minutes long, and answered questions that I've found valuable in the community. 

Reception has been great, and this practice has gotten my proverbial wheels rolling again. I also do them all in one take (low production quality) with a whiteboard.

However, my YouTube needs content too. The ideation process in Maker School is quite easyâ€”I just scroll through the posts and find one that I consider interesting. Can I do the same thing for YouTube?

A preliminary example of this might involve me scrolling through X or LinkedIn. And then finding, say, 3 developments/posts that I find interesting. I use one for the packaging (e.g "Claude Cowork"), write a reasonably sexy title "Claude Cowork: Now Coworking You Out Of Business" etc, and talk about that subject first. Afterwards, I cover the two others. Whiteboard when necessary, etc.

The biggest thing, I feel, would be to simply quell that voice in my head that says the content sucks. Weirdly, it seems like I consider the content in Maker School to be inherently okay, since within my group I'm the end-all, be-all authority, and I suppose I'm used to the idea that they enjoy content off-the-cuff. But on YouTube, I internally believe the bar is higher or something, because I commonly don't want to publish content unless it's super polished. So I need to overcome this.

I suppose that's just the perfectionism I've always struggled with. I can beat this no differently to how I've beaten the rest (basically, just publishing shit anyway even if I feel it sucks).

I will of course spend a moment to think about what I want to say before saying it. Think MoistCritical-style intros. But I believe this is feasible.

What's more, I could weave that directly into my Maker School stuff. I could do the Maker School uploads first, as a warm-up, since I consider the bar lower. After I feel good, I could upload it as a community exclusive, and while it's uploading, record the YouTube video. Would be a good batch use of time as well.

Okay, I think I'll do this. Next is just me figuring out a content curation method that effectively finds three high-quality, interesting developments to comment on.

I'll try X first.
Okay, my habit muscle is back. 10th day tomorrow and I think I've instilled this. Last 7 days have averaged 95% sleep score. Have taken supplements every day. I am ready to create content again.

Today marks Day 9 of my routine.

Much harder. Why?

- I had a call in the morning that broke me up mid-routine.
- This turned into two calls, ~2hrs.
- I then had to eat lunch, which took me to ~2.5hrs.
- Felt satiated and kept pushing work back. ~3hrs.

Next time, need to make sure to record content ASAP after finishing community management. Then I have to go to the gym immediately. Habit stacking only works if you act on the triggers right away, after all. If I don't anticipate I can finish my routine before my first call of the day, I must wake up earlier. Just how it is.

Now I'm doing agency work! Tired and it's only 12:50pm. Tomorrow will be better.

Today marks Day 8 of my new routine.

Working very well. Yesterday I was probably the happiest I'd been in ~2 months. 

I really do need some form of daily, progressive overload to feel satisfied. Though it eventually got tiresome, my Daily Updates were extremely helpful in that regard.

Things to change in the routine:
- I'm persistently forgetting to do my Anki. I must find a way to conceptually tie this to me physically entering the gym.
- The content I'm recording for Maker School is good. Very Daily-Update-esque. People like it and I'm improving my ability to talk about content again. This is clearly my zone of competence. I should do something very similar for my YouTube channel and just post. After ~1-2wks I'm confident I'll pick up some steam, and as long as I find a bank of content to draw from I think I can easily outperform anyone on YouTube (given the fact that I am more articulate and more interesting).
- I need to stop having Poke bowls right after the gym. I love those things, and it's great protein-wise, but the high sodium goes against my current goals.

I'll think more about this. But yeah, 8 days in a row of gym + actionables has me feeling great. I wonder how I'll feel at 80 days!

Coming to the conclusion that Twitter just doesn't work for me. Too much going on, I keep getting drawn to the (frankly) interesting political developments. I do not want to become a Professional Situation Monitor; these people go nowhere. I want to play in the arena itself.

So I'm going to stop posting my updates here. Instead, I'll come up with some vibe coded solution using Claude that posts to a feed. A bright 16yo called Tejas built me a good example (https://t.co/9slf2He2n2) and I think I'll run with something like this.

It'll be simple, short, and straightforward. I'll use it as both my work log and my thought log over the course of a day. My own little "X" without any of the algorithmic bullshit. Then I'll delete my personal Instagram, my personal X, my personal Facebook, everything.

Will see results in ~2wks.

Wake up, protein + coffee (~30g & ~200cal), supplements, community mgmt. Then content. 1:21.

After, back day. 7x/wk program. While I was there, I did Anki flashcards in between sets (took ~5 minutes). Supersets got the workout down to 0:37.

Total: 1:58!

But if you have a gym connected to an internal space, like an apt, you avoid all of that. No outfit changes, your "commute" is just an elevator ride, and you save ~35-40% of your sum time. Worthwhile investment when I make ~$2.5K/hr all in (30min/day x 30d/mo = ~$37.5K/mo!)

All this to say: definitely going to move. Investing in a place with a great apartment gym is worth a lot. I'm a bit limited in Calgary, as the top-end of the market is quite restricted and there isn't much optionality. But other areas (Vancouver, Toronto) are pretty good.

That's... actually not all that much. I could probably just respond to all of them as part of my daily routine. 

Bet it would significantly improve conversions + reputation, since creators never do this.

I tried going fully offline this holiday season to explore whether I was missing some quintessential aspect of "vacation", like everyone around me was suggesting. But frankly, I think they're wrong. A sliding scale of productivity works far better for me than a 0/1.

All this to say, I am back and excited to build a long chain of output again. All of my best results have been from small daily habits compounded by time.

Well, I tried a "vacation" this year for the first time in my life. Turned everything off (emails, phone, Skool, etc). 

Had a good time, but my $0.02 is that it was completely unnecessary. Did not gain more enjoyment than I would have if I had continued my daily actionables.

Can't believe I wasn't paying for meal prep before. Saves at least 30min/day, not accounting for other quality of life improvements (food storage, meal variety, macros calculated for me, etc).

Biggest hack, though, is the lack of cleaning. Dish needs completely eliminated. I just transfer food into the same bowl so I don't reheat plastic, and then rinse it immediately.

Key here was building a script that combined all emails into a unified interface (my own little unibox), so I can run bulk threads and manage stuff in each mailbox in one place. Then it's as simple as getting mail for the day -> asking Opus what's spam, what's sponsorship, etc.
Set up email filters for everything using Opus-4.5.

You can totally use Opus-4.5 as an inbox manager now. Didn't used to be able to, too likely to fail. But now you just store context about you/your business (even URLs) in a kb.json file and it'll do great.

Imagine if I had access to a local supercomputer to do stuff like this. Would be so much faster. No wonder big orgs often speak so optimistically. If I could run inference on one of these models at 100x and saw them blaze through tasks, I would think AGI was here too.

So much has happened in just 4 hrs.

- Vastly improved processing times by swapping one-off endpoints with bulk/batch endpoints (~20x speedup).
- Scrape> enrich > AI personalization now takes ~15 mins for 10K leads.
- I built a fully autonomous AI setter (and it's GOOD!)

Insane.

- Proposal generation
- Lead scraping
- Lead enrichment

- Campaign copywriting
- Adding to tool

Unfortunately ran into rate limits. Moving back over to CC. Going to double check first and see if concepts map over 1:1, and if perf is similar, or if sonnet-4.5 is dumber.

New scraper run completely with Antigravity Python scripts. Very cool. /workflows and /scripts seem to be the most reliable way of doing this. Result: ~30 second query > 6K emails for $15, 4K non-email records that I passed through AMF for 25% enrichment rate at $0.01/per ($10).
Ordered first 3 days of DFY meal prep (test).

Created Antigravity lead scraping workflow. TLDR automates Apify <> Google Sheets. I will build this out into a full cold email scraping flow soon, then dump into the appropriate Instantly campaigns, then run.
Yeah, that's the way to do it. Future businesses will probably run entirely off of terminals like this.

Experimented more with Antigravity. Pretty cool. I believe the play is:
- Start with natural language workflow (SOP)
- Store this in /workflows.
- Generate Python scripts to handle each. Store this in /scripts.

When /workflow called -> execute scripts. Much more reliable.

Ideated calendar backfill automation. In short, instead of me keeping my calendar open from say 1pm to 4pm, I backfill my calendar by exposing 3:30pm-4:00pm. When that's booked, I programmatically expose 3pm to 3:30pm. Etc etc. That way, my meetings are all back-to-back.

Structure: /sops folder will contain breakdowns of tasks that exist in /tasks. This seems the most scalable infrastructure to me. https://t.co/v30Jw7OTAe
PostToolUse is my favorite. Must have the notif be customized though. I had "Completed Task" for a while and that was pointless

Ok going to start live stream of consciousness updating with all of the Claude hacks/learnings over the course of the next few hours

hooks are huge. tying these hooks to notifs are also huge. especially with multiple claude instances, and when it requires updates https://t.co/WALuiRKmNT

hooks are huge. tying these hooks to notifs are also huge. especially with multiple claude instances, and when it requires updates https://t.co/WALuiRKmNT

speaking via voice is huge. Aqua -> Claude Code saves a lot of time and keeps hands off the keyboard

Context7 is the meta-mcp which makes all other API docs possible. Instead of using MCP and storing them in your context window (massive token drain and makes perf worse), just use Context7 and then look up API docs

https://t.co/u3I0ZLcKf5 should be minimal since it's attaching to every instantiation. This has worked ok for me https://t.co/TzLAymH9Z2

Also, since Claude Code for agency contexts (basically using it as my agent to take tasks) doesn't really work on the current repo a ton, you can just run multiple claude code instances w/o worktrees or any magic like that. Just fire up 3 and run them constantly

Claude often creates files in the current working directory but doesn't remove them after work is done. To eliminate bloat, add a line like "if you need to create temporary files/etc during task execution, do so in a /temp folder to keep things organized unless otherwise asked"
